ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Economics of Chemical Engineering, ASPEN HYSYS
An economic evaluation of chemical plants, Monte Carlo and Crystal Ball Simulations.
A better understanding of everything being an engineer entails, not just the core chemistry and physics.
I learned a lot about designing a chemical processing plant and about presentation as a skill
A lot of industry terminology and analysis skills.
How to write a technical report, work in a team, and develop an economic analysis of a project.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that the course does not have a lot of rigor and this causes students to slack off. Also, in other universities the process of making the capstone project is the opposite of what we did in class: study and develop a chemical process and have everything work -then, you do the economic analysis. You do not do the project for the sake of the analysis.
Professor is super chill but the project can be quite difficult to comprehend and magical works from the heavens will descend upon you as you finish the project.
I think Yehia does a good job of making us work on the project gradually rather than it being stressful towards the end of the semester.
chill not but not a lot of learning. Yehia is a nice guy but the final project is tedious.

I think the structure of the course was pretty good overall. I think I would have liked to do a more different project from the other groups (we all did more or less the same thing) but besides that I was happy with everything.
Prof Khalil is a really kind and knowledgeable professor. He's always out to help students which makes the course strong.
It's an economics class for chemical engineers which goes about as well as you can expect. Some of the principles, especially surrounding depreciation, were really confusing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Monte Carlo brought a crystal ball at the start of the semester and as he rubbed the ball every night, revelations came to him in dreams, and by the end of the semester, the Capstone project was complete. Good luck my dear seniors!
Yes, I would recommend to graduating chemE majors.

I would recommend this course overall.  Prof. Khalil is extremely knowledgable and really wants to see his students succeed, he is there for you every step of the way.  Overall it was not as challenging as I thought it would be but I still feel like I got a lot out of it and am proud of our project in the end.
If it is with Khalil, then yes. He makes the process easy by giving constant feedback and preparing us for the presentations.
